6 Arrays

Pyret arrays are built-in, mutable, fixed-length, and indexed by non-negative integers starting at 0. Like Lists, in the current incarnation of Pyret they are heterogeneous, though you can write a parameterized annotation for them (e.g. Array<Number>).

Two arrays are == (and as a consequence, can be compared with is) if and only if they are identical. To compare them for equality in testing, the array-to-list function or to-list methods are useful as they take an immutable snapshot of the Array’s contents.

6.1 Constructing Arrays

array

fun array(l :: List<a>) -> Array<a>:  end

Create a new array with the elements of l

array-of

fun array-of(v :: a, n :: Number) -> Array<a>:  end

Create a new array of length n with all elements initially set to v

build-array

fun<a> build-array(f :: ( Number -> a ), n :: Number) -> Array<a>:  end

Call f with numbers from 0 to n, creating an array from the results

6.2 Manipulating Arrays

There are a few constructs for working with arrays. Array indexing is 0-based, so the first element is at position 0.

array-get

fun array-get(v :: Array<a>, n :: Number) -> a:  end

Get element at position n

array-set

fun array-set(v :: Array<a>, n :: Number, v :: a) -> Array<a>:  end

Mutably update the element at position n. Returns the updated array.

array-length

fun array-length(v :: Array<a>) -> Number:  end

Return the number of elements in the array

array-to-list

fun array-to-list(v :: Array<a>) -> List<a>:  end

Return a list with the elements of v in the same order

6.3 Array Methods

Array.get

get(self :: Array<a>, n :: Number) -> a

 

check:

  a = array([1,2])

  a.get(0) is 1

  a.get(1) is 2

end

Accesses the item at position n. Method version of array-get.

Array.set

set(self :: Array<a>, n :: Number, v :: a) -> Array<a>

 

check:

  a = array([1,2])

  a.get(0) is 1

  a.set(0, 42) is a

  a.get(0) is 42

end

Mutably updates the item at position n. Method version of array-set.

Array.length

length(self :: Array<a>) -> Number

 

check:

  a = array([1,2])

  a.length() is 2

  a = array([])

  a.length() is 0

end

Return the number of elements in the array. Method version of array-length.

Array.to-list

to-list(self :: Array<a>) -> List<a>

 

check:

  a = array([1,2])

  a.to-list() is [1,2]

end

Return the elements in the array as a list. Method version of array-to-list.
